case_vignette:
A 54-year-old woman comes to the clinic for an annual check-up. She has no other complaints except for some weight gain over the past year. Her last menstrual period was 8 months ago. “I started eating less since I get full easily and exercising more but just can’t lose this belly fat,” she complains. She is sexually active with her husband and does not use any contraception since “I am old.” She denies vaginal dryness, hot flashes, fevers, abdominal pain, or abnormal vaginal bleeding but does endorse intermittent constipation for the past year. Physical examination is unremarkable except for some mild abdominal distension with fluid wave. Laboratory findings are as follows:

Serum:
Na+: 138 mEq/L
Cl-: 97 mEq/L
K+: 3.9 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen: 21 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
Glucose: 120 mg/dL
B-hCG: negative
question: What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've gained some weight over the past year and I get full easily even when I eat less, but I can't seem to lose the belly fat. I've also had intermittent constipation for the past year.
Have you noticed any blood in your stools or abdominal pain?
No, I haven't noticed any blood in my stools or had any abdominal pain.

Have you been regularly screened for gastrointestinal conditions, such as colon cancer?

**Final Diagnosis:** Constipation with functional obesity.

Further evaluation, such as a pelvic exam or imaging studies, may be necessary to rule out other conditions.
